definition[0]: to live or stay in a place
example[0]: He occupies the house without paying any rent.
example[1]: The building was purchased and occupied by its new owners last year.
definition[1]: if something occupies you or your time, you are busy doing it
example[2]: Football occupies most of my leisure time.
example[3]: Only six percent of police time is occupied with criminal incidents.
definition[2]: to fill a particular amount of space
example[4]: Family photos occupied almost the entire wall.
explanation[0]: In everyday English, people usually say that something takes up time or space rather than occupies it:
example[5]: Work takes up most of her time.
example[6]: That bed takes up almost the whole room.
definition[3]: to enter a place in a large group and keep control of it, especially by military force
example[8]: Students occupied Sofia University on Monday.
definition[4]: to use something such as a room, seat, or bed
example[9]: Many patients who are occupying hospital beds could be transferred to other places.
definition[5]: to have an official position or job
example[10]: Before becoming prime minister, he had already occupied several cabinet posts.
definition[6]: to use a particular building to live or work in
example[11]: a large computer company that occupies a building of some 60,000 sq ft
example[12]: He occupies an important position in government.
definition[7]: if something is occupying you, you are busy doing it
example[13]: As PA to the chief executive, there is plenty to keep you occupied.
example[14]: Mr Ball is occupied with a customer at the moment.
definition[8]: to use a particular amount of space or time
example[15]: Computer files occupy much less storage space than paper ones.
example[16]: Running the business occupies nearly all of her time.
